0.00.text:
Translator: Tijana Mihajlović
Reviewer: Denise RQ

132.46.text:
Adam Ockelford: Right.
Thanks very much, Derek.

134.73.text: It's wonderful to be here in Warwick.

137.50.text:
I promise there won't be
too much of me talking,

139.75.text: and a lot of Derek playing,

141.21.text: but I thought it would just be nice

142.90.text:
to recap on how Derek got
to where he is today.

148.00.text:
It's amazing now,
because he's so much bigger than me,

151.78.text:
he could have fitted
on the palm of your hand.

157.32.text:
and really, it was a fantastic fight
for him to survive.

162.76.text: He hadn't have a lot of oxygen,

164.75.text: and that affected your eyes, Derek,

166.74.text:
and also the way you understand language,
and the way you understand the world.

171.75.text: But that was the end of the bad news,

173.54.text:
because when Derek
came home from hospital,

176.77.text:
his family decided
to employ the redoubtable nanny

179.79.text:
who was going to look after you, Derek,
really for the rest of your childhood.

184.74.text:
And nanny's great insight,
really, was to think,

188.76.text:
"Here's a child who can't see.
Music must be the thing for Derek."

193.09.text:
And sure enough, she sang,
or as Derek called it, warbled to him

198.51.text: for his first few years of life.

200.77.text:
I think it was that excitement
with hearing her voice,

206.52.text:
that made him think maybe, you know,
in his brain something was stirring,

213.80.text:
Here's a little picture 
of Derek going up now,

216.28.text: when you were with your nanny.

220.27.text: Nanny's great other insight was to think,

223.78.text:
"Perhaps we should get Derek
something to play,"

227.09.text:
and sure enough, she dragged
this little keyboard out of the loft,

231.76.text:
never thinking really
that anything much would come of it.

235.48.text:
But Derek, your tiny hand
must have gone out to that thing

239.80.text:
bashed it so hard they thought
it was going to break.

242.78.text:
But out of all the bashing,
after a few months,

249.97.text:
and I think there was just
a miracle moment, really, Derek,

253.27.text:
when you realized that all the sounds
you hear in the world out there

258.70.text:
is something that you can copy
on the keyboard.

261.29.text: That was the great eureka moment.

264.22.text:
Now, not being able to see meant,
of course, that you taught yourself.

267.55.text: Derek Paravicini: I taught myself to play.

269.58.text:
AO: You did teach yourself to play,
and as a consequence,

272.97.text:
playing the piano for you, Derek,
was a lot of knuckles and karate chops,

276.43.text: and even a bit of nose going on in there.

279.06.text:
Here's what nanny did also do
was to press the record button

284.02.text:
on one of those little,
early tape recorders that they had,

288.04.text:
and this is a wonderful tape
of Derek playing

290.18.text:
when you were 4 years old,
having taught yourself.

293.96.text:
AO: It wasn't actually
"Cockles and Mussels."

337.48.text: AO: There you are. That was a bit...

348.04.text: There's this little child who can't see,

349.98.text:
can't really understand much
about the world,

352.51.text:
has no one in the family
who plays an instrument,

354.83.text: and yet he taught himself to play that.

357.04.text: As you can see from the picture,

358.62.text:
there was quite a lot of body action
going on while you were playing, Derek.

362.49.text:
Now, along - Derek and I met
when he was four and a half years old,

367.16.text:
and at first, Derek,
I thought you were mad, to be honest,

370.77.text: because when you played the piano,

372.56.text:
you seemed to want to play
every single note on the keyboard,

375.51.text:
and also you had this little habit
of hitting me out of the way.

378.53.text:
So as soon as I tried
to get near the piano,

383.25.text:
Having said to your dad, Nic,
that I would try to teach you,

387.00.text:
I was then slightly confused
as to how I might go about that

389.87.text: if I wasn't allowed near the piano.

392.26.text:
But after a while, I thought, well,
the only way is to just pick you up,

396.31.text:
shove Derek over
to the other side of the room,

398.53.text:
and in the 10 seconds
that I got before Derek came back,

401.66.text:
I could just play something
very quickly for him to learn.

405.73.text: In the end, Derek, I think you agreed

407.55.text:
that we could actually have some fun
playing the piano together.

411.23.text:
As you can see, there's me in my early,
pre-marriage days with a brown beard,

420.07.text:
I just realized this is going
to be recorded, isn't it? Right. Okay.

426.10.text:
By the age of 10, Derek really
had taken the world by storm.

430.30.text: This is a photo of you, Derek,

431.84.text:
playing at the Barbican
with the Royal Philharmonic Pops.

436.68.text:
Basically it was just
an exciting journey, really.

441.37.text:
In those days, Derek,
you didn't speak very much,

443.77.text:
and so there was always
a moment of tension

445.81.text:
as to whether you'd actually understood
what it was we were going to play

449.29.text:
and whether you'd play
the right piece in the right key,

451.95.text: and all that kind of thing.

453.27.text: But the orchestra were wowed as well,

455.74.text: and the press of the world were fascinated

458.23.text:
by your ability
to play these fantastic pieces.

462.90.text:
Now the question is,
how do you do it, Derek?

465.75.text:
Hopefully we can show the audience now
how it is you do what you do.

471.50.text: I think that one of the first things

473.25.text:
that happened
when you were very little, Derek,

475.51.text: was that by the time you were two,

477.14.text:
your musical ear had already outstripped
that of most adults.

482.28.text:
So, whenever you heard any note at all
- if I just play a random note -

488.99.text: you knew instantly what it was,

491.01.text:
and you'd got the ability as well
to find that note on the piano.

496.91.text: and some people have perfect pitch

499.22.text:
for a few white notes
in the middle of the piano.

507.27.text:
You can see how - you get
a sense of playing with Derek.

514.50.text:
But Derek, your ear
is so much more than that.

517.03.text:
If I just put the microphone
down for a bit,

519.12.text: I'm going to play a cluster of notes.

521.75.text:
Those of you who can see
will know how many notes,

525.54.text: Not only can you say how many notes,

527.48.text:
it's being able to play them
all at the same time.

546.03.text:
It's that ability, that ability
to hear simultaneous sounds,

551.99.text:
but when a whole orchestra is playing,
Derek, you can hear every note,

555.29.text:
and instantly, through all those
hours and hours of practice,

560.07.text:
that makes you, I think,
is the basis of all your ability.

566.80.text:
It's no use having that kind
of raw ability without the technique,

572.31.text:
and luckily, Derek, you decided that,
once we did start learning,

575.51.text:
you'd let me help you
learn all the scale fingerings.

578.51.text:
So for example using your thumb
under with C major.

594.01.text: In the end, you got so quick,

596.53.text:
that things like "Flight of the Bumblebee"
were no problem, were they?

601.20.text:
AO: Right. So here, by the age of 11,
Derek was playing things like this.

677.52.text:
AO: Yeah. Alright, Derek,
let's have a bow. Well done.

696.70.text:
The truly amazing thing was,
with all those scales, Derek,

701.97.text:
"Flight of the Bumblebee"
in the usual key

703.93.text: but any note I play, Derek can play it on.

707.30.text:
So if I just choose
a note at random, like that one.

711.13.text:
Can you play "Flight of the Bumblebee"
on that note?

713.60.text:
DP: "Flight of the Bumblebee"
on that note.

721.21.text: AO: Or another one? How about in G minor?

734.52.text:
So you see, in your brain, Derek,
is this amazing musical computer

742.51.text:
all the pieces in the world
that are out there.

744.72.text:
Most pianists would have
a heart attack if you said,

747.27.text:
"Sorry, do you mind playing
'Flight of the Bumblebee'

749.80.text:
in B minor instead of A minor?"
as we went on.

752.11.text:
In fact, the first time, Derek,
you played that with an orchestra,

755.70.text:
you'd learned the version
that you'd learned,

757.82.text:
and then the orchestra, in fact,
did have a different version,

760.74.text:
so while we were waiting in the 2 hours
before the rehearsal and the concert,

764.39.text:
Derek listened to the different version
and learned it quickly

767.34.text:
and then was able to play it
with the orchestra.

770.77.text:
The other wonderful thing
about you is memory. DP: Memory.

774.77.text:
AO: Your memory is truly amazing,
and every concert we do,

777.99.text:
we ask the audience
to participate, of course,

781.39.text:
by suggesting a piece
Derek might like to play.

785.91.text:
because what happens
if Derek doesn't know it?"

788.11.text: I say, "No, it's not brave at all,

789.75.text:
because if you ask for something
that Derek doesn't know,

792.47.text:
you're invited to come and sing it first,
and then he'll pick it up." (Laughter)

797.57.text:
before you suggest
something too outlandish.

800.06.text:
But seriously, would anyone like
to choose a piece?

803.74.text:
DP: Choose a piece. Choose, choose,
would you like to choose?

806.65.text:
AO: Because it's quite dark.
You'll just have to shout out.

809.43.text: DP: Would you like to hear me play?

812.71.text:
AO: Paganini.
DP: "The Theme of Paganini".

933.81.text:
because it means that Derek and I
will have spent over 100 hours

938.63.text:
which is quite interesting,
isn't it Derek?

941.51.text:
DP: Very interesting, Adam, yes.
Long-haul flights. Yes.

944.14.text:
AO: You may think 13 hours
is a long time to keep talking,

946.87.text:
but Derek does it effortlessly.
Now then. (Laughter)

951.47.text:
But in America, they've coined this term,
"the human iPod" for Derek,

954.97.text:
which I think is just missing
the point, really,

957.24.text:
because Derek, you're so much more
than an iPod.

963.48.text:
and I think that was nowhere
clearer to see, really,

966.28.text: than when we went to Slovenia,

968.52.text:
and someone - in a longer concert
we tend to get people joining in,

973.78.text:
and this person very, very nervously came
onto the stage.

977.25.text:
DP: He played "Chopsticks".
AO: And played "Chopsticks".

981.29.text: AO: A bit like this. DP: Like this. Yes.

985.56.text:
AO: I should really get Derek's manager
to come and play it. He's sitting there.

991.17.text: AO: Just teasing, right? Here we go.

995.51.text: AO: What did you do with it, Derek?

997.28.text: DP: I got to improvise with it, Adam.

999.07.text: AO: This is Derek the musician.

1143.95.text: I think the TED people will kill me,

1145.79.text: but perhaps there's time for one encore.

1147.82.text: DP: For one encore. AO: One encore, yes.

1151.51.text: So this is one of Derek's heroes.

1153.26.text: It's the great Art Tatum - DP: Art Tatum.

1155.49.text:
AO: - who also was a pianist
who couldn't see,

1157.67.text:
and also, I think, like Derek,
thought that all the world was a piano.

1162.71.text:
it sounds like there's 3 pianos
in the room.

1164.98.text:
Here is Derek's take
on Art Tatum's take on "Tiger Rag".
